Comment: While there's a common concern that immigration lowers wages for native-born workers, most economic studies find little or no impact on wages for the average American worker [1, 2, 3]. Some studies even suggest that immigration can lead to wage increases for some groups, particularly for those with less education, according to research from the National Bureau of Economic Research | NBER https://www.nber.org/papers/w32389 [18]. [1, 2]   Here's a more detailed look: [1, 2]    • Studies with Neutral or Positive Effects: Many economists have found that immigration does not significantly reduce wages for native-born workers. Some studies even indicate that immigration can lead to wage increases, particularly for less-educated native workers. [1, 2, 3, 4]   • Immigration and Complementarity: Immigrants often complement native-born workers rather than competing with them directly. For example, low-skilled immigrant workers can allow native-born workers in higher-skilled occupations to specialize and increase their productivity, according to the Brookings Institute https://www.brookings.edu/articles/what-immigration-means-for-u-s-employment-and-wages/ [1]. [1, 5]   • Immigration and Business Growth: Immigrant workers can also stimulate business growth by creating demand for goods and services, which can lead to increased employment and wages for both immigrants and native-born workers, says the Brookings Institute https://www.brookings.edu/articles/what-immigration-means-for-u-s-employment-and-wages/ [1]. [5]   • Potential for Some Negative Impacts: Some studies have suggested that immigration may have a slightly negative impact on wages for low-skilled native-born workers in specific industries where they compete directly with immigrants. However, these effects are generally considered to be small and localized. [5]   • Wage Elasticity: Some research suggests that a 10% increase in the number of immigrants might lead to a 0.2% decrease in wages for native-born workers, but this is not a widely accepted finding, according to the Cato Institute https://www.cato.org/cato-journal/fall-2017/does-immigration-reduce-wages [7].
